Please use the sharing tools found via the email icon at the top of articles. Copying articles to share with others is a breach of FT.com T&Cs and Copyright Policy. Email licensing@ft.com to buy additional rights. Subscribers may share up to 10 or 20 articles per month using the gift article service. More information can be found at https://www.ft.com/tour.
https://www.ft.com...-857e-cdc960e6545e

Chinese carmaker Great Wall has expressed interest in buying Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, the company said on Monday.

A spokesman for the Chinese group told the Financial Times: “We have always had the interest and intention to acquire FCA.”

FCA, which also owns the Jeep, Ram, Alfa Romeo and Maserati brands, has been searching for a buyer in order to cut development costs of electric and self-driving cars.
Chief executive Sergio Marchionne, who is due to retire in 2019, has previously made unsuccessful overtures to General Motors and Volkswagen Group about buying the company.

But seeking to sell one of the three major US carmakers to a Chinese buyer with Donald Trump in the White House would present something of a political hurdle.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

So ..... we knew already that FCA's for sale, yes?

PM11:07am

We did

PM11:08am

Anyone who could buy it has said No. Repeatedly

11:08 am

And China is the default buyer of all legacy engineering assets in the west that no one else wants.

PM11:08am

Still, FCA stock up 3% this morning

PM11:08am

11:08 am

PM11:09am

BE11:09am

Want some UBS here?

11:09 am
PM11:10am

Sure!

BE11:10am

Have to admit, I'd never heard of Great Wall before this morning.

BE11:10am

Jeep sold 1.4m SUVs globally in 2016, a segment that enjoys high growth and solid
profitability. We cannot comment on the merit of the story, but from Great Wall’s
perspective, we believe a potential acquisition of the Jeep brand would make strategic
sense. As China’s domestic leader in the SUV segment, the Jeep brand would give
Great Wall a global brand to pursue its globalization ambitions. However, from FCA’s
perspective, we are hesitant to see a strong logic for the deal as we believe (1) FCA
needs a certain critical mass for its mass-market brands (Jeep is one of them), and a sale
would put this in question; (2) Jeep and the Fiat brand have some platform
commonality, ie, there would be negative synergies for the Fiat brand in case of a sale.
CEO Marchionne also said in the recent Q2 analyst call that in case of asset disposals,
what remains in the group needs to be fit for survival on a stand-alone basis, alluding
to the relevance of economies of scale. Eventually, a potential deal could be a question
of valuation. We do not have a separate valuation for Jeep in our SOTP model because
FCA discloses its mass-market brands only on an aggregated basis by region, but
assume that the Jeep brand will contribute ~€3bn of EBIT in 2017E, or ~40% of group
EBIT.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

UBS completely ignoring the Trump reality?

BE11:12am

Yes. So are Maybank, if you want them too.

PM11:12am

Why not

11:12 am
BE11:12am

FCA will spin off its luxury brands including Maserati and Alfa Romeo and wants to sell the rest of the business. This is not only JEEP but other brands including Fiat and Chryslers, etc with production plants in both EU and US. This is a complicated multi-brands business. Great Wall’s market cap is around USD16b which is lower than FCA’s USD20b.

BE11:13am

We believe this is positive to Great Wall if it can
acquire part of the business such as Jeep and RAM
brands. We believe both companies could generate
positive synergies in the SUV market. However, Great Wall may need to raise capital for the deal in our view. Separately, Guanghzhou Auto says the company has no plan to buy Fiat Chrysler.

BE11:13am

According to a document today by the State Council,
China will limit overseas investments by domestic
companies in sectors including real estate and sports clubs, while encouraging them to invest in
infrastructure and new technology. We believe China government will likely also support such acquisition.

Both the hotel and supermarket have been pre-let. The redevelopment is expected to complete in late 2018, which will, subject to satisfying various contractual conditions, trigger the completion of the acquisition.

BE11:24am

Hikma, the London-listed generic drugmaker, has sharply increased the price of a string of medicines in the US — including a diarrhoea treatment that has risen 430 per cent — in the latest instance of “gouging”.

West-Ward Pharmaceuticals, the US division of Hikma, raised the price of six of its drugs at the start of the month by between 75 per cent and 430 per cent, according to figures seen by the Financial Times. The mean increase was 237 per cent.

The average wholesale price of a 60ml bottle of liquid Atropine-Diphenoxylate, a common diarrhoea drug better-known by the old brand name Lomotil, went from about $16 a bottle to $84 — meaning a single dose of the 35-year-old medicine now works out at $14.

BE11:25am

All that stuff about balanced portfolio of generics post the Roxane purchase ... Nah, let's just to predatory pricing. Neat.

BE11:28am

Post 1H we lower EPS by 35% as we not only take a cautious approach to the
base business but also stress test the bear case by removing Gx Advair from our
model given ongoing uncertainty; we believe this base case lowers modeled
intrinsic risks and gives optionality on Gx Advair, allowing us to focus on core
fundamentals which we believe leaves limited downside. We therefore upgrade
to HOLD as believe fundamental drivers are now skewed to the upside.

BE11:28am

Weaker US generics reflects wider industry pressures; no Gx Advair update was
disappointing: We lower sales to Hikma’s c.$620m sales guidance (JEFe $621m); we
would hope it is a floor and there is upside in 2H, but believe it is prudent not to assume so
at this point. We forecast $32m EBIT vs. guidance $30m as forecast some GM contraction
with pricing pressure which is expected to continue into 2018 – these changes lead EPS
lower by c.9-10%. We completely remove Gx Advair (15%-20% EPS impact) to focus on core
fundamentals, which leaves upside to investors.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

We believe injectables margin guidance has more downside than upside risk:
We lower injectables sales by 2% to $778m vs. lowered $775m guidance. Given the decline
was due to higher margin products we were surprised to see margin guidance firmed at
“39%” vs. “high 30’s” previously. We raise margins to 38% vs. 36% previously (benefiting
‘17E EPS by 3.7%). Our revised forecast is below guidance and implies a 36.5% 2H margin
(vs. 39.8% 1H) as we assume a greater impact from glycopyrrolate competitors and a slower
uptake of new products. We leave our 2018+ margins unchanged; hence lower sales impacts
EPS by c.1.5%

BE11:29am

2H branded weighting is a high hurdle: 1H sales declined by 16% as FX continued
to bite, especially in Egypt. The recently expanded partnership with Takeda should help
momentum but we view reported growth guidance of “broadly in-line with 2016“ as -4% (vs.
JEFe +1% previously) despite a 2H boost from seasonality, timing of launches and FX base
impact. HIK expects absolute core EBIT to be “in-line with 2016”. JEFe $106.3m vs. $112.0m in
2016; this implies 20bp margin contraction to 19.9% which still requires a 21% 2H margin;
hence are below guidance and cons. Branded changes lower our EPS by c.2-2.5%.

PM11:29am

(epicurean - nope sorry.)

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Peel Hunt also holders, albeit reluctantly.

BE11:30am

We downgrade our price target and medium to long-term EPS forecasts by 30% on the back of our view that (i) headwinds in the generics industry can intensify further, and (ii) Hikma is less able to offset these through its acquisition of the Boehringer assets than we previously believed. Last week’s H1 results release brought another in a series of guidance downgrades, and the disparity between Hikma’s and Mylan’s commentaries on the timelines for their respective Advair generics filings seems to add support to Mylan’s claim that it will be first to market. The shares have been swift to discount these incremental concerns (the stock is down c15% since the H1 release); so upside to our TP remains despite our downgrades, keeping us at Hold.

PM11:35am

The intended launch configuration for this slot will enable additional fuel to be embarked upon HYLAS 4 enabling it to reach geostationary orbit approximately 90 days earlier than would otherwise be the case.

Therefore, assuming the current launch manifest is maintained, HYLAS 4 will achieve geostationary orbit at approximately the same time as the previously announced launch date. Consequently, HYLAS 4 revenues would be expected to flow from July 2018 as previously planned.

Furthermore, this configuration also provides a lower mission risk profile and enables sufficient fuel to be embarked to support the satellite for up to 19 years in orbit, an increase of 27% over previous expectations.

PM11:36am

So if the satellite is going to be up there and working for 27% longer, that makes it substantially more valuable, I guess.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

The large UK-proxy property companies are particularly prone to UK-centric
economic and political events
BLND’s accounting returns (annual NAVPS growth plus dividend / starting NAVPS)
have fallen from 24.5% in FY15 to 2.7% in FY17, a fall of 89% (see our report The
UK Real Estate Sector – an unsustainable market relative valuation, March 2015).
This has resulted in an entrenched p/book discount for much of the sector in
anticipation of returns now turning negative (as our estimates continue to indicate).
Our lowered target price of 678p (from 738p) forms the basis of a sustainable free
cash flow yield of 5.3% (FY18e) and a p/book discount of 22% (vs our FY18 871p
NAVPS forecast) which is not bad value. However, the large UK-proxy property
companies are particularly prone to UK-centric economic and political events, which
has evidently left them devoid of any re-rating impetus, underscored by a declining
UK GDP growth trajectory. As a result, we downgrade to Hold from Buy until there is
more discernible directional evidence.

British Land Company PLC (BLND:LSE): Last: 605.00, down 6 (-0.98%), High: 607.00, Low: 602.00, Volume: 1.57m
BE11:42am

Mike Prew also has his newsletter out this morning.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(@WajneJ: I haven't been able to get hold of Pig World since they redeveloped Berwick Street.)

BE11:43am

He's in good, bearish form as usual.

BE11:44am

Investment agents will be nervously returning to their desks after the summer
break hoping the investment market will recommence with the same gusto it left off. It
won't. The Chinese money underpinning platinum grade asset trades at a 100bps yield
‘entry tax’ premium for a trade up in property right, transparency, liquidity and land law
was always exposed to a regulatory tourniquet, and that tightened on Friday, the day after
we issued our REIT Quarter: “After the Mahjong Money, What Next?’. Bloomberg News
reported: ‘China to Limit Overseas Investment in Property, Hotels, Sports. China will restrict
domestic companies from investing in sectors such as real estate, hotels, entertainment industry
and sports clubs, according to a State Council guideline on overseas investment posted on
government website. China will also ban overseas investment in gambling businesses. The story
could just as easily have read’ China will also ban overseas gambling in investment business’,
and the next foreign buying spree in UK commercial real estate will come at a high yield/
low price. An illustrative 50bps yield shift on a 4% yielding building gives a 12% price
reduction, and add in -5% in rents for starters geared 30% LTV is -25% off your equity. Take
our worst case rental decline of -20% and you get a near halving in equity.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The best source
of buying prime assets is the REITs. They all took de-gearing too far after QE started
to reprice the market post the GFC, and now they are shoehorning portfolios into shapes
promised to shareholders and are increasingly on the back foot as the cycle turns. BLND's
share buyback isn’t working (BLND hasn’t got surplus cash and has only bought 3.6m shares
for £22.6m out of £300m) and is belatedly de-gearing by selling assets the market will buy
rather than the higher yielding secondary assets it should have jettisoned in 2014 at the peak
of the 'dash for trash' when LAND sold Sunderland at a 25% premium to book. EGi reports
that 5 Broadgate (UBS ground-scraper 710,000 sq ft BLND/GIC JV) may be sold and BLND
is reported to have taken valuation advice from CBRE and JLL. Across Bishopsgate, RBS has
agreed on a deal with Ivanhoe Cambridge Inc. to sell its London HQ office building but
for less than the £145m asking prices (BB) after Premier Place went up for sale in June as
RBS downsizes the banks property portfolio and costs. Private HK investor Advanced Idea
Holdings emerged as the buyer for the £271.4m (let on long-term leases to insurer XL Group
with a 90k sq ft Marks & Spencer at a value of £1,382psf on a NIY 4.2%) acquisition of 70
Gracechurch Street (CoStar) from L&G in the investor’s first property acquisition in the UK.

BE11:45am

Remember our maxim that you lose money quickly in London offices and only
a little less quickly in shopping centres; the retail story is going sour. British shoppers
carried on in July but at much slower rates, with rising inflation and anemic wage growth
seeing the first fall in real incomes in two years.
